children.name: to make a bad or difficult situation worse
make things worse/make it worse
children.definition: /ˌmeɪk θɪŋz ˈwɜːʳs, ˌmeɪk ɪt ˈwɜːʳs/  to make a bad or difficult situation even worse, especially when you were trying to improve it:
examples: ▪ Don’t interfere. You’ll only make things worse.
▪ Trying not to laugh aloud made it worse, and for a moment or two, they were both helpless with suppressed laughter.
▪ Why not try running the anti-virus software? It can’t make things any worse, can it?

children.name: to make matters/things worse
children.definition: /tə ˌmeɪk mætəʳz, θɪŋz ˈwɜːʳs/  use this to talk above something that makes a bad situation even worse:
examples: ▪ To make matters worse, the director’s gone on holiday without leaving anyone in charge.
▪ To make things worse, Jimmy suddenly announced he’d left his passport at home.

children.name: aggravate
children.definition: /ˈægrəveɪt/  to make a bad or difficult situation even worse:
examples: ▪ Air pollution may aggravate a child’s asthma.
▪ Is the pain aggravated by coughing or laughing?
▪ Any talk of price rises now will only aggravate an already serious situation.

children.name: exacerbate
children.definition: /ɪgˈzæsəʳbeɪt/  formal to make a bad or difficult situation even worse:
examples: ▪ The family’s problems were exacerbated when Walter lost his job.
▪ Ironically, the government’s reassurances may have exacerbated fear about the disease.

children.name: compound
children.definition: /kəmˈpaʊnd/  if somethingcompoundsa problem, mistake, or difficulty, it adds to the existing problem so that the general situation gets even worse than before:
examples: ▪ Strong nationalist sentiment is compounding the deep political problems faced by the President.

children.name: be compounded by
examples: ▪ John and Val’s domestic problems were compounded by stress at work.
▪ The effects of the East Coast snows this year were compounded by severe storms in the spring.

children.name: to add insult to injury
children.definition: /tʊ æd ˌɪnsʌlt tʊ ˈɪndʒəri/  use that to say that something makes a bad situation worse for someone, by unfairly giving them another problem that relates to or is a result of the original one:
examples: ▪ The bank not only refused to refund the money but, to add insult to injury, charged me for the letter telling me so!
